title: Boeing replaces head of commercial aircraft division
text:
However, he was also the executive responsible for resolving the problems with the 737.

His unexpected departure comes just the day before Boeing was widely expected to announce in third-quarter results another multibillion-dollar hit to profits as a result of the global grounding of its 737 MAX aircraft.

The 737 MAX 8 has been banned from flying by aviation authorities around the world after two fatal crashes within five months left hundreds dead.

Last July, Boeing announced a $US4.9 billion ($7.2 billion) after-tax charge related to the grounding in its first estimate of the cost of compensating airlines for schedule disruptions and delays in aircraft deliveries.

The departure also comes as Boeing faces spiralling criticism over its disclosure of information relating to the automated software system that has been blamed for the two crashes.

A series of text messages sent in 2016 by two Boeing technical pilots — who prepare training simulators and manuals — was leaked last Friday. These appeared to suggest that Boeing had long been aware of problems with the aircraft’s anti-stall system, known as the manoeuvring characteristics augmentation system, or MCAS.

However, Boeing has argued that these texts had been handed over to the US Department of Justice after the first crash in October 2017 and were not about problems with the software, but with the simulator.

Nevertheless, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration last week publicly reprimanded Boeing over its failure to disclose the texts to the regulator until recently. The strained relationship between Boeing and the FAA has raised concerns that the timetable for re-certifying the 737 MAX could now be delayed into next year.

S &P this week revised its outlook on Boeing from stable to negative, but retained its A credit rating. It cited the texts and concern that the aircraft’s return to service could be delayed. It also said the events of recent days could “have a lasting impact on the company’s reputation, competitive position, profitability, and — ultimately — its financial strength”.

Boeing this week put out a progress report of all the steps it is taking to address the problems of the 737. It said that all the upgrades to MCAS had been completed and handed to the FAA.

“The company continues to work with the FAA and other global regulators on the process laid out for certifying the 737 MAX software and related training updates,” it said. “The company has also made significant governance and operational changes to further sharpen its focus.”

Mr Muilenberg is due to appear before Congress for two days next week. It will the first time lawmakers have a chance to grill Boeing directly about the circumstance that led to the crashes.

Financial Times
description: Boeing has replaced the head of its commercial aeroplanes division, marking the most significant leadership change in the wake of two deadly 737 MAX crashes.
